english: so stuffed; overfull; bloated; (implying) idle and looking for trouble

etymology.description: 撑(撐, to be overfull; to prop up) + 的(structural particle) = state/adjectival phrase meaning 'so stuffed/overfull,' also implying 'idle and itching for trouble.'
etymology.interpretation: Colloquial state phrase where 的 turns 撑 into a descriptive condition; often written as 撑得 when marking degree/complement. Figuratively suggests being so full and idle that one looks for trouble.
etymology.simplification: 撐 → 撑 by simplifying component 爭 → 争 under the hand radical; 的 unchanged.

examples.chinese: 我午饭吃多了，肚子撑的难受(我午飯吃多了，肚子撐的難受)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ wǔfàn chī duō le, dùzi chēng de nánshòu.
examples.english: I ate too much at lunch; my stomach feels uncomfortably full.

examples.chinese: 你这是撑的没事干，非要去惹事(你這是撐的沒事幹，非要去惹事)。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ zhè shì chēng de méi shì gàn, fēi yào qù rěshì.
examples.english: You're so idle from being overfull that you’re looking for trouble.

examples.chinese: 包子别再塞了，袋子都撑的鼓鼓的了(包子別再塞了，袋子都撐的鼓鼓的了)。
examples.pinyin: Bāozi bié zài sāi le, dàizi dōu chēng de gǔgǔ de le.
examples.english: Stop stuffing buns in; the bag is already stretched full.
